newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK legislators vote to extend pension office funds.
newsitem.headline: HK legislators vote to extend pension office funds.

text.p: The Finance Committee of Hong Kong's Legislative Council (Legco) has voted to extend funding to keep the territory's proposed pension scheme alive, a Legco spokeswoman said.

The committee voted by a margin of 31 to 19 to extend to the Mandatory Provident Fund office the HK$25 million (US$3.2 million) that will keep it operational for the 13 months from March, allowing it to complete its work.
The MPF office is charged with recommending guidelines to balance the risks and returns of MPF investments.
The MPF as planned would require individual employees and employers to each contribute five percent of a monthly salary to a retirement fund.
On January 29, the establishment sub-committee of the Legco Finance Committee voted by a margin of 11 to six to deny funding to the MPF office.
Opponents of the MPF charged that workers' assets would be at risk because the funds would be managed by the private sector rather than by the Hong Kong government.
Some said they preferred a system similar to Singapore's Centralised Provident Fund.
Opponents also expressed fears that lower-paid workers would be left out of the scheme and about the plan's cost.
Since the funding was voted down by the sub-committee in January, the MPF office has made concessions to soothe the opposition's concerns about the scheme.
For example, the MPF office has said that it may be possible to design a scheme that would offer guaranteed returns.
The plan also could include rules that would bar scheme providers from rejecting any clients.
